item.title: Euro-Zone Wage Growth Sinks, Supporting Further ECB Easing
item.description: A key measure of euro-area pay growth plunged, supporting the European Central Bank’s claim that inflation will soon hit the 2% target and backing calls to lower interest rates further.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber, Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: European Union flags outside the headquarters of the European Central Bank (ECB) in Frankfurt.

item.title: Bulgaria Is on Track to Win EU Approval to Join the Euro Next Year
item.description: Bulgaria is close to clearing a major hurdle toward euro adoption, putting the Black Sea nation on course to join the currency area next year.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Viktoria Dendrinou, Slav Okov

media:content.media:description: Sofia, Bulgaria.

item.title: Zambia Halts Rate Hikes as Corn Boom Seen Cooling Inflation
item.description: Zambia’s central bank held its key interest rate as it expects the disinflation process to continue.
item.dc:creator: Taonga Mitimingi

media:content.media:description: Traders at a market along a railway line in Lusaka, Zambia.

item.title: Trump Calls Japan’s Ishiba Ahead of Latest Tariff Talks
item.description: US President Donald Trump initiated a phone call with Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba and discussed tariffs in general terms, just as Tokyo’s top negotiator left for the US for another round of trade talks.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara, Akemi Terukina

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba, Japan's prime minister and president of the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), during the party's annual convention in Tokyo, Japan, on Sunday, March 9, 2025. Japan’s lower house passed the budget for the year starting in April, checking off a key item on Ishiba’s to-do-list for shoring up his leadership ahead of a national election in the summer.

item.title: Sweden’s Central Bank Seen Cutting Rate Next Month in Survey
item.description: The Riksbank, which signaled a slight easing bias at its last meeting, will probably deliver a quarter-point reduction in Swedish borrowing costs already next month, according to a survey of economists by Bloomberg that contrasts with market pricing.
item.dc:creator: Ott Ummelas, Harumi Ichikura

item.title: RBI Governor Sees India Growth Moderately Hit on Tariff Woes
item.description: India’s economic growth will see a short-term impact of the ongoing tariff tensions, the central bank governor said, though the South Asian nation will stay resilient amid geopolitical and trade uncertainties.
item.dc:creator: Anup Roy, Ruchi Bhatia

media:content.media:description: Sanjay Malhotra Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg

item.title: German Economy Grew More Than Initially Thought at Start of Year
item.description: Germany’s economy grew twice as much as initially estimated at the start of 2025 as businesses and exporters attempted to get ahead of expected US tariffs, setting up the country for a rude awakening in the coming months.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow

media:content.media:description: Customers at a restaurant terrace in Bremen, Germany, on Saturday, May 3, 2025. Friedrich Merz sought to move past an embarrassing stumble as he took power in Germany, vowing to reboot the economy and revive the country’s military.

item.title: Poland’s Surging Stocks Tested by Neck-and-Neck Runoff Election
item.description: The slump in Polish stocks, one of the year’s global equity standouts, signals that traders are increasingly jittery about any more political surprises.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Krasuski

media:content.media:description: Stock prices and trading data on digital boards at Warsaw Stock Exchange in Warsaw, Poland, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Poland’s central bank cut interest rates for the first time since October 2023 as eastern Europe’s biggest economy prepares to elect a new president in a little over a week’s time.

item.title: ECB’s Stournaras Sees Interest-Rate Cut in June and Then a Pause
item.description: The European Central Bank may leave borrowing costs unchanged for the time being after a likely quarter-point reduction next month, according to Governing Council member Yannis Stournaras.
item.dc:creator: Sotiris Nikas, Paul Tugwell, Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: Yannis Stournaras, governor of Bank of Greece, during a Bloomberg Television interview in London, UK, on Thursday, Nov. 21, 2024. "As inflation develops now and as the real economy develops now, I think yes we should have a cut in every meeting from now on until we get to what we call the neutral rate," Stournaras said. Photographer: Betty Laura Zapata/Bloomberg

item.title: Indonesia Picks New Tax, Customs Chiefs to Improve Revenues
item.description: Indonesia appointed new heads for its tax and customs offices amid a sharp decline in revenue collections.
item.dc:creator: Grace Sihombing

media:content.media:description: Indonesian 10,000 rupiah banknotes on a tray at a currency exchange office in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Thursday, Oct. 5, 2023. The dollar’s relentless rally has finally toppled the last Asian currency standing, with the Indonesian rupiah joining regional peers in erasing this year’s gains against the greenback. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

item.title: US Firms Face Biggest Hit on Trump Tariffs, HSBC Survey Says
item.description: US businesses are the most worried about the impact of President Donald Trump’s shifting tariff policies on their revenues, with more than half projecting a hit of at least 25% to their revenue, according to a survey by HSBC Holdings Plc.
item.dc:creator: Harry Wilson

media:content.media:description: The HSBC Holdings Plc UK headquarters in London. Photographer: Betty Laura Zapata/Bloomberg

item.title: Soaring UK Retail Sales Defy Headwinds in Boost for Reeves
item.description: UK retail sales soared in April, continuing a surprisingly strong start to the year and offering hope that the economy can defy headwinds from tax hikes, rising household bill and US President Donald Trump’s global tariff war.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: Shoppers in the city centre in Leeds, UK, on Saturday, Dec. 21, 2024. UK retail sales grew more slowly than expected in November suggesting Christmas shoppers might not boost the economy in the crucial final months of the year.

item.title: S. Korean Presidential Race Tightens Sharply After TV Debate
item.description: South Korean presidential candidate Lee Jae-myung saw his lead in the election campaign narrow sharply in the latest opinion poll released Friday as the conservative ruling party’s Kim Moon-soo made up ground after their first TV debate.
item.dc:creator: Shinhye Kang, Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: SEOUL, SOUTH KOREA - MAY 18: (L to R) South Korea's presidential candidates, Kim Moon Soo of the People Power Party, Kwon Young-guk of the Democratic Labor Party, Lee Jun-seok of the New Reform Party and Lee Jae-myung of the Democratic Party pose for photograph ahead of a televised presidential debate for the forthcoming June 3 presidential election at SBS studio on May 18, 2025 in Seoul, South Korea. South Korean voters will head to the polls to replace ousted President Yoon Suk-yeol on June 3. (Photo by Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images) Photographer: Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images AsiaPac

item.title: Hungary’s Orban Signals Economy Headwinds May Persist Into 2026
item.description: Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban signaled potential further delays in kick-starting the nation’s economy into next year, citing the uncertainty around peace efforts in neighboring Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Andras Gergely

media:content.media:description: Viktor Orban Photographer: Atdhe Mulla/Bloomberg

item.title: EU and US to Hold Trade Call Friday Amid Differences on Tariffs
item.description: The European Union’s trade chief, Maros Sefcovic, is planning to hold a call with Jamieson Greer, his US counterpart, on Friday to take stock of talks, according to a European Commission spokesperson.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: European Union flags in Brussels, Belgium. Photographer: Simon Wohlfahrt/Bloomberg

item.title: South Africa Expects US Reset Despite White House Showdown
item.description: South Africa’s finance chief said the government made progress on resetting its relationship with the US and securing a trade deal in talks that took place after President Cyril Ramaphosa’s showdown with Donald Trump at the White House.
item.dc:creator: Ntando Thukwana, S'thembile Cele

media:content.media:description: Enoch Godongwana

item.title: UK Energy Bills to Drop 7% Offering Relief to Households
item.description: UK energy bills will fall 7% from July after a dip in wholesale gas prices, providing some relief to households and businesses who are still struggling with high costs.
item.dc:creator: Eamon Farhat

item.title: Singapore Core Inflation Quickens for First Time Since Sept.
item.description: Singapore’s key inflation gauge accelerated for the first time since September, driven by an increase in healthcare, education and food prices.
item.dc:creator: Phila Siu

media:content.media:description: Customers eat at the Hong Lim Market and Food Centre in Singapore on Tuesday, April 27, 2021. As part of the Hawkers Go Digital program that offered incentives like cash payouts, more than 10,000 stallholders, or about half of the total on government-owned premises, have adopted e-payment solutions, according to a statement by the government agencies in charge of the program. Photographer: Wei Leng Tay/Bloomberg

item.title: Ghana Set to Hold Key Rate to Hasten Disinflation
item.description: Ghana’s central bank is set to continue its tight monetary policy stance to hasten the pace of disinflation toward its year-end target.
item.dc:creator: Ekow Dontoh

media:content.media:description: Johnson Asiama Photographer: Ernest Ankomah/Getty Images

item.title: India Says US Trade Talks Were ‘Constructive’ on Bilateral Deal
item.description: India’s Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal said that he had a “constructive meeting” with his counterpart Howard Lutnick for a mutually beneficial trade agreement between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: Ruchi Bhatia

media:content.media:description: Piyush Goyal, India's minister of railways, commerce and industry, speaks during the India Energy Forum by Ceraweek in New Delhi, India, on Tuesday, Oct. 15, 2019. The conference provides insight into the Indian and regional energy future by addressing key issues from India's energy transition; provision of heat, light and mobility; sustainability; expanding use and game-changing industry technologies. Photographer: Anindito Mukherjee/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan’s Akazawa Heads to US for Third Round of Trade Talks
item.description: Japan’s top trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa set off Friday for the US for a third round of trade talks with the Trump administration, with Tokyo determined to avoid a deal that doesn’t address levies on its key auto industry.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara, Akemi Terukina

media:content.media:description: Ryosei Akazawa in Washington, DC, on May 1. Photographer: Stefani Reynolds/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan’s CPI Pickup, Rice Price Surge Raise Pressure on Ishiba
item.description: Japan’s key inflation gauge accelerated to the fastest clip in more than two years, with soaring rice prices exacerbating Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba’s troubles after a cabinet shakeup over controversial comments by his agricultural chief on the nation’s staple food.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

media:content.media:description: A customer shops for rice at a Marusan supermarket in Koshigaya, Saitama Prefecture, Japan, on Sunday, March 16, 2025. One year on from Japan’s historic rate hike, profits at its biggest banks are soaring to records, while price rises are forcing consumers to cut back and higher borrowing costs are fueling a political battle over how the government can rein in its outlays.

item.title: Senior US-China Officials Vow to Keep Communication Lines Open
item.description: Beijing and Washington continued high-level contact with a Thursday call between senior officials, a sign that the two sides are maintaining active communications following their trade truce earlier this month.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy

media:content.media:description: The US and China flags stand behind a microphone awaiting the arrival of US Senator John McCain, who was joined by Senators Lindsey Graham Amy Klobuchar for a press conference at the US Embassy in Beijing on April 9, 2009 during the China stop of the Congressional Delegation's fact-finding Asia-tour. Senator McCain said he urged Chinese officials in talks here to back a strong United Nations response to North Korea's rocket launch, but indicated China had resisted. AFP PHOTO/Frederic J. BROWN (Photo credit should read FREDERIC J. BROWN/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Lagarde Says International Trade Will Never Be the Same
item.description: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde warned that international trade will be changed forever by the tensions over tariffs, even as the world’s leading economies edge toward some compromises.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin, Erik Hertzberg

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde, president of the European Central Bank (ECB), speaks at 'The Transformative Power of AI: Economic Implications and Challenges' conference in Frankfurt, Germany, on Tuesday, April 1, 2025. Euro-area inflation eased further toward the European Central Bank’s 2% target as officials weigh whether or not to continue lowering interest rates.

item.title: UK Consumer Confidence Gains on Interest-Rate Cut, US Trade Deal
item.description: UK consumer confidence rebounded slightly in May, a new survey showed, as the Bank of England eased borrowing costs and government officials struck a trade deal with the US.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

item.title: BOJ’s Ueda Refrains From Hinting at Action Over Bond-Yield Surge
item.description: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda refrained from indicating he’s prepared to take action in the bond market after yields on super-long dated securities hit a record high, amid a continuing effort to improve trading conditions.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: Kazuo Ueda, governor of the Bank of Japan (BOJ), speaks during a news conference at the central bank's headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, May 1. The BOJ left its benchmark rate unchanged while pushing back the timing for when it expects to reach its inflation target amid intensified uncertainties due to US tariff measures.

item.title: Argentina Signals to Investors IMF Cash to Come Despite Reserves
item.description: Argentine officials signaled to investors in London last week they expect to receive a $2 billion disbursement from the International Monetary Fund next month regardless of whether they miss a target for rebuilding foreign reserves just a few months into a new program.
item.dc:creator: Zijia Song, Kevin Simauchi

media:content.media:description: The Central Bank of Argentina in Buenos Aires.

item.title: US Will Stop Making New Pennies, Citing Savings and Low Demand
item.description: The US government is ending production of the penny, citing drastically decreased demand and immediate savings.
item.dc:creator: Mark Niquette

media:content.media:description: A pile of US pennies is seen in this photo illustration in Washington, DC, February 10, 2025. US President Donald Trump said on February 10, 2025, that he has told the US Treasury to stop producing penny coins, presenting it as an effort to cut down on government spending. (Photo by SAUL LOEB / AFP) (Photo by SAUL LOEB/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: Saul Loeb/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Stephen Miran Explains Why There’s No Secret Dollar Pact
item.description: On today’s Big Take DC podcast, the Chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers talks market volatility and currency policy.
item.dc:creator: Saleha Mohsin, Rachael Lewis-Krisky, Chris Anstey

media:content.media:description: Stephen Miran Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

item.title: G-7 Warns of ‘Excessive Imbalances’ in Global Economy
item.description: Finance ministers and central bank governors from the Group of Seven nations pledged to address “excessive imbalances” in the global economy, an effort clearly aimed at China, though the final communique omitted the name of the country.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Jorge Valero, Erik Hertzberg, William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, during a House Financial Services Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Bessent said he’s working with US legislators on outbound investment rules for China that would make clear what’s allowed and what’s not.
